toxins.name: Eucalyptus Essential Oil
toxins.chemical_formula: Not explicitly provided in the sources.
toxins.description:
in cats:
    ◦ Hepatic Enzyme Deficiency: Cats lack specific liver enzymes (glucuronyl transferase) required to break down and eliminate the volatile compounds found in essential oils. This inability to process the toxins leads to a buildup in the body, which can cause serious organ damage, specifically liver failure.
    ◦ Central Nervous System (CNS) Depression: The oils can affect the nervous system, leading to symptoms such as seizures, tremors, and a "drunk-like" uncoordinated gait (ataxia).
    ◦ Respiratory Irritation: Inhalation of the oil (via diffusers or sprays) can irritate the respiratory tract, causing difficulty breathing. This risk is heightened in cats with pre-existing conditions like asthma.
    ◦ Gastrointestinal and Dermal Irritation: Direct contact or ingestion can cause chemical burns on the skin or mouth, excessive drooling, and vomiting.
toxins.concentration_notes:
◦ Highly Concentrated: Essential oils are highly potent. Toxicity can occur from ingestion (licking oil off fur), direct skin contact (even a single drop of concentrated oil can be problematic), or inhalation.
    ◦ Neat vs. Diluted: The oils are especially dangerous if used "neat" (undiluted). However, even diluted oils or ambient exposure from reed diffusers and nebulizers can pose a risk.
    ◦ Dried Plant Material: While the oil is most potent, the dried plant parts can still cause issues if ingested.• Are essential oils toxic to cats? - PDSA1,2,3,4
• Household Hazards: Toxic Hazards for Cats | VCA Animal Hospitals5
• Lavender Poisoning in Cats - Wag! (General essential oil mechanism)6,7
• Is Lavender Poisonous to Cats? | La Belle Fleur (General essential oil mechanism)

symptoms.name: Vomiting, Diarrhea, and Excessive Drooling (Hypersalivation)
symptoms.onset: Rapid (Clinical signs often appear quickly after ingestion or contact).
symptoms.notes: Drooling is often the first sign, caused by the burning sensation of the oil in the mouth or nausea. Vomiting helps expel the toxin but can lead to dehydration.Neurological Depression and Disturbances

symptoms.name: Lethargy, Depression, Ataxia (walking as if drunk/uncoordinated), Tremors, and Seizures
symptoms.notes: Essential oils are rapidly absorbed. Because cats lack the liver enzyme (glucuronyl transferase) needed to break down these compounds, toxins build up, depressing the central nervous system. Severe cases can lead to collapse or coma.Respiratory Distress

symptoms.name: Difficulty Breathing (Dyspnea), Wheezing, or Coughing
symptoms.onset: Rapid (Especially if the oil is inhaled via a diffuser or aspirated during vomiting).
symptoms.notes: Inhalation of strong vapors from diffusers can irritate the airways, causing an inflammatory response. This is particularly dangerous for cats with pre-existing conditions like feline asthma.Dermal Irritation

symptoms.name: Chemical Burns, Redness, and Soreness
symptoms.notes: Essential oils are highly potent and can burn the skin upon direct contact. Cats may also ingest the oil while grooming the irritated area, leading to systemic poisoning.Hepatic (Liver) Failure

symptoms.name: Liver Damage / Failure
symptoms.onset: Delayed (May develop over days as the body fails to metabolize the toxins).
symptoms.notes: This is the most serious long-term risk of essential oil exposure. Signs may include jaundice (yellowing of eyes/gums) and progressive weakness.

treatments.name: Surface Decontamination and Oral Rinsing
treatments.description:
◦ Dermal: If the cat has essential oil on its skin or fur, the veterinarian (or owner under instruction) will bathe the cat using liquid dish soap and lukewarm water to remove the oil before it is absorbed through the skin or ingested during grooming.
    ◦ Oral: If ingested, the vet may rinse the cat's mouth with water to remove residues.
treatments.notes: Inducing vomiting (emesis) at home is not recommended for cats as it can cause further injury or aspiration. The veterinarian will determine if inducing vomiting at the clinic is safe based on the cat's neurological status and the time since ingestion.Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy

treatments.name: Aggressive Fluid Therapy
treatments.description: The administration of IV fluids is used to correct dehydration caused by vomiting and diarrhea. Crucially, it also helps support kidney and liver function by flushing toxins from the bloodstream and maintaining organ perfusion.
treatments.notes: Since essential oils like Eucalyptus can cause serious organ damage (specifically liver failure), fluid support is vital to help the body eliminate the toxins and support the liver.Respiratory Support and Symptomatic Care

treatments.name: Oxygen Therapy and Symptomatic Medication
treatments.description:
◦ Respiratory: If the cat has inhaled Eucalyptus vapors (e.g., from a diffuser) and is showing signs of respiratory distress (coughing, wheezing), the vet will administer oxygen.
    ◦ Neurological/GI: Medications such as anti-emetics (to stop vomiting) and anticonvulsants (if seizures or tremors occur) are administered to stabilize the patient.
treatments.notes: Eucalyptus toxicity can manifest as central nervous system depression (lethargy, "drunk" walking) or overexcitement (tremors, seizures). Monitoring liver enzymes is also critical as liver damage is a known risk of essential oil poisoning.
